meta.title: Current Affairs MCQs
meta.description: Multiple choice questions on recent events and developments in Pakistan and around the world.

questions.q: Who is the current Prime Minister of Pakistan?

questions.q: What is the significance of the Resolution of Lahore (Pakistan Resolution)?
options: It demanded a separate homeland for Muslims of British India.
It called for independence from British rule.
It established the first political party.
questions.ex: The Resolution of Lahore, passed in 1940, was a formal political statement by the All-India Muslim League calling for a separate homeland for the Muslims of British India.

questions.q: Which Pakistani province has the longest coastline?

questions.q: What is the main judicial body of Pakistan?

questions.q: What is the current literacy rate in Pakistan (approximate)?

questions.q: Which Pakistani dam is the largest in terms of water storage capacity?
questions.ex: Tarbela Dam on the Indus River is the largest earth-filled dam in the world and has the largest water storage capacity in Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the National Accountability Bureau (NAB) in Pakistan?

questions.q: Which international organization is responsible for global financial stability?

questions.q: What is the term for a widespread occurrence of an infectious disease in a community at a particular time?

To regulate global currency exchange rates

questions.q: What is the name of the international treaty on the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity?

questions.q: Which international organization focuses on nuclear safety and security?
questions.ex: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is the world's centre for cooperation in the nuclear field.

questions.q: What is the primary driver of recent global inflation?
options: Supply chain disruptions and energy prices
questions.ex: Recent global inflation has been largely attributed to supply chain disruptions, increased energy prices, and post-pandemic economic recovery.

questions.q: Which country is a permanent member of the UN Security Council?

questions.q: What is the term for the forced displacement of people from their homes?
questions.ex: A refugee crisis refers to a situation involving the large-scale forced displacement of people.

United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)

questions.ex: Islamabad is the capital city of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the name of the treaty that demarcates the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan?

questions.q: Which year did Pakistan conduct its first successful nuclear tests?
questions.ex: Pakistan conducted its first successful nuclear tests (Chagai-I) in 1998.

questions.q: What is the role of the Election Commission of Pakistan (ECP)?
questions.ex: The Election Commission of Pakistan is an independent, autonomous, permanent and constitutional body responsible for organizing and conducting elections.

questions.q: Who is the Commander-in-Chief of the Pakistan Armed Forces?
questions.ex: The President of Pakistan is the Commander-in-Chief of the Pakistan Armed Forces.

questions.q: What is the name of Pakistan's intelligence agency?
questions.ex: The Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) is the premier intelligence agency of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the official name of the Parliament of Pakistan?

questions.q: Which bill aims to protect women against harassment in Pakistan?
options: Protection against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act
questions.ex: The Protection against Harassment of Women at the Workplace Act, 2010, is a key law in this regard.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the National Accountability Bureau (NAB) in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The National Accountability Bureau (NAB) is Pakistan's autonomous and constitutionally established federal institution responsible to combat corruption and investigate.

questions.q: What is the role of the Leader of the Opposition in the National Assembly of Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Leader of the Opposition plays a crucial role in scrutinizing government policies and providing an alternative viewpoint.

questions.q: Which province of Pakistan has the largest area?
questions.ex: Balochistan is the largest province of Pakistan by area.

questions.q: What is the role of the Attorney General for Pakistan?
options: Principal legal advisor to the government
questions.ex: The Attorney General for Pakistan is the chief legal advisor to the Government of Pakistan.

questions.q: Which is the longest-serving political party in Pakistan?
questions.ex: The Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) has been a prominent political force in Pakistan for a significant period.

questions.q: What is the primary objective of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)?
questions.ex: CPEC is a collection of infrastructure projects under construction throughout Pakistan, aiming to boost economic growth.

questions.q: Who was the first military ruler of Pakistan?
questions.ex: Ayub Khan was the first military ruler and second President of Pakistan.

questions.q: What is the significance of the 23rd March in Pakistan's political history?
questions.ex: 23rd March is celebrated as Pakistan Resolution Day, commemorating the adoption of the Lahore Resolution.

questions.q: What is the current number of administrative units (provinces and territories) in Pakistan?
questions.ex: Pakistan consists of four provinces (Punjab, Sindh, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Balochistan) and two autonomous territories (Azad Jammu and Kashmir, Gilgit-Baltistan).

questions.q: Who is the current Secretary-General of the United Nations?
questions.ex: António Guterres is the current Secretary-General of the United Nations.

questions.q: Which international organization is responsible for maintaining international peace and security?
questions.ex: The United Nations (UN) is the primary international organization dedicated to maintaining international peace and security.

questions.q: What is the G7?
options: A group of the world's seven largest developed economies
questions.ex: The G7 is an informal bloc of seven major advanced economies.

questions.q: Which international treaty aims to combat climate change?
questions.ex: The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty on climate change.

questions.q: What is the primary purpose of NATO?
questions.ex: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is a military alliance based on the principle of collective defense.

questions.q: Which country is NOT a permanent member of the UN Security Council?
questions.ex: Germany is not a permanent member of the UN Security Council; the permanent members are China, France, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

questions.q: What is the official currency of the European Union?
questions.ex: The Euro is the official currency of the Eurozone, which consists of 20 member states of the European Union.

questions.q: Which international court is responsible for prosecuting individuals accused of genocide, war crimes, and crimes against humanity?
questions.ex: The International Criminal Court (ICC) investigates and, where warranted, tries individuals charged with the gravest crimes of concern to the international community: genocide, war crimes, crimes against humanity and the crime of aggression.

questions.q: What is the Non-Aligned Movement?
options: A group of states not formally aligned with or against any major power bloc
questions.ex: The Non-Aligned Movement is a forum of 120 developing world states that are not formally aligned with or against any major power bloc.

questions.q: Which agreement established the World Trade Organization (WTO)?
questions.ex: The World Trade Organization (WTO) was established by the Marrakesh Agreement in 1994.

questions.q: What is the UN's primary humanitarian aid agency?
questions.ex: The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) is the primary UN agency responsible for coordinating humanitarian aid.

questions.q: Which treaty ended World War I?
questions.ex: The Treaty of Versailles, signed in 1919, officially ended World War I.

questions.q: What is the main focus of the International Labour Organization (ILO)?
questions.ex: The International Labour Organization (ILO) is a United Nations agency whose mandate is to advance social justice and promote decent work by setting international labour standards.

questions.q: Which organization is responsible for international financial stability and monetary cooperation?
questions.ex: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is a major financial agency of the United Nations, and an international financial institution.

questions.q: What is the UN Human Rights Council responsible for?
questions.ex: The UN Human Rights Council is an intergovernmental body within the United Nations system responsible for strengthening the promotion and protection of human rights around the world.

questions.q: Which international agreement aims to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons?
questions.ex: The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) is a landmark international treaty whose objective is to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons and weapons technology, to promote cooperation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, and to further the goal of achieving nuclear disarmament.

questions.q: What is the G20?
options: A forum for international economic cooperation
questions.ex: The G20 is an international forum for the governments and central bank governors from 19 countries and the European Union.

questions.q: Which city is the headquarters of the International Criminal Court (ICC)?
questions.ex: The seat of the International Criminal Court (ICC) is in The Hague, Netherlands.

questions.q: What is the primary goal of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) set by the UN?
options: To achieve a better and more sustainable future for all
questions.ex: The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) are a collection of 17 interlinked global goals designed to be a 'blueprint to achieve a better and more sustainable future for all'.

questions.q: Which organization is responsible for coordinating public health activities internationally?
questions.ex: The World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for international public health.

questions.q: What is the term used to describe the removal of trade barriers between countries?
questions.ex: Trade liberalization is the removal or reduction of restrictions or barriers on the free exchange of goods and services between nations.

questions.q: Which international treaty governs the law of the sea?
options: Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties
United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)
questions.ex: The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) is an international treaty which establishes a legal framework for all marine and maritime activities.

questions.q: What is the primary function of the International Court of Justice (ICJ)?
options: To prosecute individuals for war crimes
To settle legal disputes between states
questions.ex: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) is the principal judicial organ of the United Nations and settles legal disputes between states.

questions.q: Which alliance was formed during the Cold War by the Soviet Union and its satellite states?
questions.ex: The Warsaw Pact was a collective defense treaty signed in Warsaw, Poland, between the Soviet Union and seven Eastern Bloc satellite states of Central and Eastern Europe during the Cold War.

questions.q: What is the purpose of UN peacekeeping operations?
options: To intervene in internal conflicts unilaterally
To help countries navigate the path from conflict to peace
To impose sanctions on hostile states
questions.ex: UN peacekeeping operations help countries navigate the path from conflict to peace. They are guided by three basic principles: consent of the parties, impartiality, and non-use of force, except in self-defense and defense of the mandate.

questions.q: Which international organization focuses on promoting education, science, and culture?
questions.ex: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations aimed at promoting world peace and security through international cooperation in education, arts, sciences, and the fostering of mutual understanding.

questions.q: What is the term for the formal withdrawal of a nation from a union or political body?
questions.ex: Secession is the act of withdrawing formally from membership of a federation or body, especially a political state.

questions.q: Which international agreement aims to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases?
questions.ex: The Kyoto Protocol is an international treaty which extends the 1992 United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) that commits state parties to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

questions.q: What is the role of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)?
options: To regulate international trade in nuclear materials
To promote the peaceful use of nuclear energy and prevent its use for any military purpose
questions.ex: The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) is the world's centre for cooperation in the nuclear field, promoting the safe, secure and peaceful use of nuclear technology.

questions.q: Which organization is responsible for protecting refugees worldwide?
questions.ex: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is a UN agency mandated to protect and support refugees at the request of a government or the UN itself.
